scenario.description: Flight from Paris (CDG) to New York (JFK) delayed 4 hours. Airline claims weather delay, and meteorological reports confirm severe thunderstorms at departure time that grounded multiple flights. Flight logs show weather as primary cause, mechanical issue was secondary response to lightning strike during taxi.

jurisdiction.reasoning: Flight departed from EU territory. EU Regulation 261/2004 applies. Same jurisdiction as mechanical delay case, but different factual circumstances.

conclusion.claim: You are likely NOT entitled to monetary compensation because weather qualifies as extraordinary circumstances. However, airline must still provide care (meals, accommodation if overnight delay).

remedy.description: You are likely NOT entitled to monetary compensation because weather qualifies as extraordinary circumstances. However, airline must still provide care (meals, accommodation if overnight delay).

uncertainties: Airline must prove weather was sole/primary cause with documentation
If mechanical issue was primary and weather secondary, compensation applies
Courts sometimes find airlines failed to prove 'all reasonable measures' taken
Lightning strike classification varies - may not always exempt airline

prior.basis: Base rate: approximately 50% of weather-related delay claims are denied compensation when airline provides documentation. However, success depends heavily on quality of airline's evidence.

evidence.factor: Airline claims weather with meteorological reports
evidence.reasoning: Weather can be extraordinary circumstance. With documentation, this decreases likelihood of compensation.

evidence.factor: Multiple flights grounded (not just this one)
evidence.reasoning: Strong evidence weather was extraordinary - affected multiple carriers, not just airline negligence.
Lightning strikes typically qualify as extraordinary. This further supports airline's exemption.

evidence.factor: Mechanical issue was secondary to lightning
evidence.reasoning: However, if airline could have mitigated mechanical issue faster, they may still be liable. Creates some uncertainty.

howToChangeMyMind: Evidence airline failed to take reasonable measures after lightning strike → confidence passenger gets compensation increases to ~0.60
Discovery that other airlines flew despite weather → confidence increases to ~0.70
Court ruling that lightning strikes don't automatically exempt airlines → confidence increases significantly

metadata.funnelJustification: Weather as extraordinary circumstance is well-established in EU 261/2004 case law, but application to specific cases remains context-dependent. Less canonical than mechanical issue case.

changelog.changes: Added comprehensive provenance disclaimers. Added submittedBy metadata. Clarified independent educational status.

disclaimer.notLegalAdvice: This is educational information, not legal advice
disclaimer.noGuarantees: We provide confidence levels (70% airline prevails in this case), not guarantees. There is a 30% chance our assessment is wrong or courts interpret evidence differently.
disclaimer.additionalNotes: This case involves competing evidence (weather vs mechanical). Attorney consultation recommended if you wish to challenge airline's determination. Success depends heavily on quality of airline's documentation and your counter-evidence.

provenanceAndLimitations.submittedBy: Passenger Rights Knowledge Base Project (independent educational initiative)
provenanceAndLimitations.notSubmittedByAuthority: This knowledge abstract was NOT submitted by an official government agency (DGAC, EU Commission, ECJ) or airline industry body. It represents our independent analysis of publicly available legal sources.
provenanceAndLimitations.verificationStatus: Unreviewed by external legal experts. Based on interpretation of primary legal sources (EU Regulation 261/2004, ECJ case law on extraordinary circumstances) and secondary sources (consumer reports, meteorological data patterns).
potentialBiases: May favor passenger interests due to project mission
Weather documentation quality assessment based on general patterns, not case-specific review
Lightning strike case law interpretation may vary by jurisdiction within EU
No review by meteorological experts or airline safety specialists
howToVerify: Request full meteorological reports from airline (you have right to see evidence)
Consult DGAC or national enforcement body for official interpretation
Check if other flights departed during claimed weather event
Obtain independent legal opinion for your specific case
Review ECJ case law on extraordinary circumstances (weather)
provenanceAndLimitations.specialConsiderations: Weather cases are more fact-intensive than mechanical delay cases. The 70% confidence that airline prevails assumes they provide comprehensive documentation. If documentation is weak or contradictory, your odds improve significantly. Key question: Did airline prove weather was sole cause AND that no reasonable measures could have prevented delay?
provenanceAndLimitations.updateMechanism: This abstract is updated based on: (1) new ECJ rulings on extraordinary circumstances, (2) weather-related precedents, (3) user-reported outcomes, (4) enforcement body guidance. Last reviewed: 2025-01-22. Next scheduled review: 2025-04-22 (quarterly).
provenanceAndLimitations.transparencyCommitment: All Bayesian reasoning, confidence calculations, and uncertainty sources are disclosed. The relatively lower confidence (70% vs 85% in mechanical case) reflects genuine uncertainty in weather exception cases. We do not artificially inflate confidence to appear more authoritative.
